Canada has huge tracts of forests covering much of it. A forest fire in 
Canada is nature's way of cleansing the forest. Talk to a forestry official 
or forest fire fighter and he (or she) will tell you that there is a huge 
build up of dry brush everywhere that has got to a critical point where 
even a small spark from an engine, a cigarette butt, etc. is all it will 
take to cause a huge forest fire. BECAUSE there is development in these 
places there is an extra effort to make sure there are no fires, so as the 
old growth trees fall down they create a build-up of more brush. Add to 
that a dry spring, when there's not much snow to go after the winter, and 
warm spring temperatures, and the forests are just fires waiting to happen. 
When they do, unless they are brought under control immediately, they can 
easily get so out of control they are beyond overcoming. The focus is then 
on trying to save real estate as the fire has to burn itself out - either 
by rain, or coming to open areas or rivers, etc. There may be all kinds of 
conspiracy theories, global warming theories, etc. but none of it changes 
the fact that Canadian forests are now tinder dry, and everyone expects to 
see the fires at this point. To NOT have such a fire, is pretty much a 
miracle at this point. Northern Canada has vast tracts of forests that go

Sir, I live in Alberta and you have made numerous assumptions that are 
incorrect.
1) We have fracking. But most of those well sites you noted are not 
fracking related. Some are, but most are oil or natural gas - coventionally 
drilled. 2) The oil activity near Ft McMurray is neither conventional nor 
fracking. It is oilsand extraction. The active portions resemble an open 
pit mine, and use steam to clean the oil from the sand, which is then 
returned to the ground and reclaimed. 3) This fire near McMurray began SW 
of the city in dense forest, no where near oil operations. 4) Northern 
Alberta, Saskatchewan and British Columbia have a very active forest fire 
season every year. The entire boreal forest ecosystem thrives on fire, and 
many tree species in this area do not open their cones to reproduce until 
they have been through a fire. I have personally seen numerous forest 
fires, and it is not at all unusal. The unusual thing is the size of this 
particular fire near a populated area. But Ft. McMurray is surrounded and 
interspersed with forest. The dry forest is all the fuel needed to keep a 
massive fire going. 5) Most forest fires in our area are one of 2 causes. 
Lightning or human activity, generally campfires improperly doused, 
careless cigarette disposal, and on very dry years, even the hot exhaust of 
a vehicle. Because of the El Nino effect, it is extremely warm and dry this 
year throughout Alberta. 6) As you said, this is a massive area and it 
would be highly improbable that one person/company should be deliberately 
setting numerous fires. There have been 361 wildfires in our province so 
far this year; 51 currently burning, 9 of which are listed as 
out-of-control. Those numbers are high compared to average, but are not 
unusual for a dry year. 7) The oil companies operating near Ft. McMurray 
have largely suspended production in order to help evacuees. They have 
chartered flights for workers so that stranded families have a place to 
stay safe in their work camps. They are chartering in supplies and sending 
out families on a priority basis. There is no road out except the one that 
goes south through Ft. Mac. It is absolutely against their best interest 
and costing them dearly when the industry is already struggling to have 
active fires. It's ludicrous to me to lay blame there. 8)We have active 
firecrews - ground, heli-attack first response, and bombers that work these 
fires every season. The use both retardant and water bombing. I personally 
know people fighting these fires and have seen the drops.﻿

+Muffy In Legal 1) Conventional oil wells are only fracked when their 
natural production stops and the rock formations need to be "fractured" to 
restart production. The majority of wells wells around Fort Mcmurray are 
primarily injection wells. Pump down some steam and the oil flows freely 
out, there is no hydraulic fracking of the rock formations here.

2) Why would you reclaim active mine sites? They're in the process of being 
mined.

3) The airport is south east of the city. The fire started in an area 
called Horse River 15 km away. Planes don't dump fuel unless it's an 
emergency, that stuffs expensive. Aircraft are only fueled enough to get to 
their destination with a little extra for leeway. An excerpt from the 
Canadian Aviation Regulations (SOR/96-433) regarding dumping:

"Fuel Dumping602.30 No person shall jettison fuel from an aircraft in 
flight unless(a) it is necessary to do so in order to ensure aviation 
safety; and(b) all appropriate measures are taken to minimize danger to 
human life and damage to the environment, insofar as the circumstances 
permit."

4) Fort Mcmurray experiences very high winds. Branches of a forest fire can 
pop up anywhere if the embers take hold. Hence how said fire was able to 
jump the Athabasca River and the firebreaks in its way. Here is a part of 
the Wikipedia article about firebreaks:

"During the worst part of the fire season in southern California, strong 
Santa Ana winds will blow carpets of burning embers across eight-lane 
freeways. During the 1988 fires in Yellowstone National Park, hot embers 
managed to cross the Lewis Canyon, a natural canyon up to a mile wide and 
600 feet (180 m) deep.[citation needed]
In Australia, firebreaks are less effective against eucalyptus forest 
fires, since intense fires in tinder-dry eucalyptus forest spread 
through flying embers, which can be carried by the winds to trigger new 
blazes several kilometers away."
